definition: fire/urgent/ammunition/fiery or flaming/internal heat (Chinese medicine)/hot (popular)/classifier for military units (old)/Kangxi radical 86
Hmong or Miao ethnic group of southwest China/surname Miao

sentences.english: He pulled off his gloves, took out his matches, and lighted the fire.
sentences.chinese: 他脫下了自己的手套，掏出了火柴，點燃了火苗。

sentences.english: A small fire can become a big fire very fast.
sentences.chinese: 小火苗會很快成爲一場大火災。

sentences.english: Snow leaves, we will hold some fire heat, flames Wang Wang's.
sentences.chinese: 下雪了我們就抱些樹葉生火取暖，火苗旺旺的。

sentences.english: In the objective environment, wood friction makes fire.
sentences.chinese: 在客觀環境中，木與木相互摩擦就會生出火苗。

sentences.english: I saw flames advancing out of that building.
sentences.chinese: 我看到火苗從那幢樓裏竄出來。

sentences.english: Keep flax from fire, youth from gaming.
sentences.chinese: 亞麻遠離火苗，青年闊別賭博。

sentences.english: I went to blow the fire aflame.
The paper burned with a yellow and blue flame and then disintegrated.
sentences.chinese: 紙被一道黃藍色的火苗吞噬，然後化成了灰。

sentences.english: A blue flame is indicative of the presence of methane in the flatus.
sentences.chinese: 藍色火苗意味着屁裏含有甲烷。

sentences.english: He fed the young flame with more wood.
sentences.chinese: 他小心翼翼地往微弱的火苗上加上更多的木頭。

sentences.english: Fanned fires and forced love never did well yet.
sentences.chinese: 扇起的火苗和勉強的愛情從來不會長久。

sentences.english: She and her family watched as their home of 20 years went up in flames.
sentences.chinese: 她和家人看着已經住了20年的房子被火苗吞噬。

sentences.english: The ashes were quickened into flames.
sentences.chinese: 撥動灰燼使火苗燃燒起來。

sentences.english: He lifted his extinguisher to put out a flame on some eye - catching fabric.
sentences.chinese: 他舉起滅火器，想撲滅一件十分惹眼的織物上的火苗。

sentences.english: The flames darted into a rick of straw with lightning swiftness.
sentences.chinese: 火苗象閃電一樣迅速地向草垛裏鑽着。

sentences.english: I turn on the coal gas stove , the red flame "shouted" fled.
sentences.chinese: 我打開煤氣竈，紅色的火苗“呼”地竄了起來。

definition: to stop burning/to go out (of fire)/to die out/extinguished
to ignite/to light/fig. to spark off (hopes, controversy, flames of revolution)
to discharge smoke/to fume with rage
